elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn005">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0020" view="all">(a) Mixed polyhedral and ball-and-stick representation of the network structure of [Mn(bpy)(1,2-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), in the <ce:italic>ac</ce:italic> plane. (b) A view along the edge of plane <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, parallel to the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>-axis. Color scheme: Mn, maroon polyhedra; P, yellow tetrahedra; oxygen, red spheres; nitrogen, light blue spheres; carbon, black spheres. Color scheme used throughout except where otherwise stated. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  (a) Mixed polyhedral and ball-and-stick representation of the network structure of [Mn(bpy)(1,2-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (1), in the ac plane. (b) A view along the edge of plane 1, parallel to the b-axis. Color scheme: Mn, maroon polyhedra; P, yellow tetrahedra; oxygen, red spheres; nitrogen, light blue spheres; carbon, black spheres. Color scheme used throughout except where otherwise stated. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0010">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn010">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0025" view="all">Mixed polyhedral and ball-and-stick representation of the layered structure of [Mn(bpy)(1,3-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) in the <ce:italic>ab</ce:italic> plane.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  Mixed polyhedral and ball-and-stick representation of the layered structure of [Mn(bpy)(1,3-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (2) in the ab plane.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0015">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn015">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0030" view="all">(a) Mixed polyhedral and ball-and-stick representation of the one-dimensional substructure of [Mn(bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(1,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)(1,4-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). (b) A view of the structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> showing the hydrogen bonding network and the expansion of the structure into two-dimensions. The layer is viewed in the <ce:italic>ab</ce:italic> plane and parallel to the chain axes of part (a) of this figure. Color scheme: as above with hydrogen as pink spheres.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  (a) Mixed polyhedral and ball-and-stick representation of the one-dimensional substructure of [Mn(bpy)2(1,4-H2O3PC8H8PO3H)(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (3). (b) A view of the structure of 3 showing the hydrogen bonding network and the expansion of the structure into two-dimensions. The layer is viewed in the ab plane and parallel to the chain axes of part (a) of this figure. Color scheme: as above with hydrogen as pink spheres.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0020">
<ce:label>Fig. 4</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn020">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0035" view="all">(a) Mixed polyhedral and ball-and-stick representation of the three-dimensional structure of [Co(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)(1,4-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>) in the <ce:italic>ab</ce:italic> plane, viewed parallel to the {Co(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)(HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PR)}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> chains. (b) A view of the structure in the <ce:italic>ac</ce:italic> plane showing the pillared layer profile. Color scheme: as above with purple polyhedra for Co.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr4"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 4  (a) Mixed polyhedral and ball-and-stick representation of the three-dimensional structure of [Co(o-phen)(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (9) in the ab plane, viewed parallel to the {Co(o-phen)(HO3PR)} n  chains. (b) A view of the structure in the ac plane showing the pillared layer profile. Color scheme: as above with purple polyhedra for Co.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0025">

<ce:caption id="cn025">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0040" view="all">A view of the one-dimensional structure of [Co(tpyprz)(1,2-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (<ce:bold>11</ce:bold>) viewed in the <ce:cross-ref id="c0185" refid="b0555">[111]</ce:cross-ref> plane.</ce:simple-para>

</ce:figure>

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0030">
<ce:label>Fig. 6</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn030">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0045" view="all">(a) A representation of the one-dimensional structure of [Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tpyprz)(1,4-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>16</ce:bold>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O). (b) A view of the structure of <ce:bold>16</ce:bold>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O showing the water molecules of crystallization. Color scheme: as about with nickel shown as green polyhedra. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr6"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 6  (a) A representation of the one-dimensional structure of [Ni2(tpyprz)(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)2]⋅4H2O (16⋅4H2O). (b) A view of the structure of 16⋅4H2O showing the water molecules of crystallization. Color scheme: as about with nickel shown as green polyhedra. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

<ce:section-title id="st145">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">A series of coordination polymers of the M(II)/xylyldiphosphonate/organoimine chelate family has been prepared by hydrothermal methods and structurally characterized. The structure of the two-dimensional, hydrogen-bonded [Ni(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(1,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(1,4-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] is shown.<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0050">
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

A series of coordination polymers of the M(II)/xylyldiphosphonate/organoimine chelate family has been prepared by hydrothermal methods and structurally characterized. The structure of the two-dimensional, hydrogen-bonded [Ni(o-phen)2(1,4-H2O3PC8H8PO3H2)(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] is shown.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0050">
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:section-title id="st150">Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">
<ce:list id="l0005">
<ce:list-item id="o0005">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0305" view="all">Coordination polymers of Mn(II), Co(II) and Ni(II) prepared by hydrothermal methods.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="o0010">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0310" view="all">Structural influence of substituent positions in xylyldiphosphonates.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="o0015">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0315" view="all">Prototypical structures of M(II)/xylyldiphosphonate/secondary ligand compounds.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="o0020">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0320" view="all">Dimensional expansion via hydrogen bonding.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="o0025">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0325" view="all">Recurrent structural motifs in coordination polymers.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
</ce:list>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Highlights

   ⋅ Coordination polymers of Mn(II), Co(II) and Ni(II) prepared by hydrothermal methods.   ⋅ Structural influence of substituent positions in xylyldiphosphonates.   ⋅ Prototypical structures of M(II)/xylyldiphosphonate/secondary ligand compounds.   ⋅ Dimensional expansion via hydrogen bonding.   ⋅ Recurrent structural motifs in coordination polymers.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0305" view="all">Coordination polymers of Mn(II), Co(II) and Ni(II) prepared by hydrothermal methods.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0310" view="all">Structural influence of substituent positions in xylyldiphosphonates.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0315" view="all">Prototypical structures of M(II)/xylyldiphosphonate/secondary ligand compounds.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0320" view="all">Dimensional expansion via hydrogen bonding.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0325" view="all">Recurrent structural motifs in coordination polymers.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st185">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">The hydrothermal reactions of the appropriate metal salt, a xylyldiphosphonic acid and a secondary organonitrogen chelating ligand yielded a series of coordination polymers of the M(II)/xylyldiphosphonate/(organoimine chelate family) with M(II) represented by Mn(II), Co(II) and Ni(II); the 1,2-, 1,3- and 1,4-isomers of xylyldiphosphonate; and the organoimine chelate present as 2,2′-bipyridine (bpy), <ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phenanthroline (o-phen) or tetra-2-pyridinylpyrazine (tpyprz). Several representative structural types were observed related to the constraints imposed by the xylyldiphosphonate ligand: the two-dimensional materials [Mn(bpy)(1,2-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Mn(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)(1,2-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) and [Co(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)(1,2-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>) constructed from {M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(N^N)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PR)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} clusters linked through the xylyl backbone of the ligands; the network structures of the series [M(bpy)(1,3-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Mn (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), Co (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>), Ni (<ce:bold>12</ce:bold>) and [M(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)(1,3-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Mn (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>) and Co (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>)) which consists of {M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(N^N)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PR)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> chains linked through the xylyl tethers; and the virtual two-dimensional series [M(N^N)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(1,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(1,4-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Mn, N^N<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>bpy (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>); M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Co, N^N<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>
<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen (<ce:bold>10</ce:bold>); and M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Ni, N^N<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>
<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen (<ce:bold>14</ce:bold>)) which contain one-dimensional {M(N^N)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(1,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">n</ce:sup>
</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> chains hydrogen-bonded to (HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions to provide expansion in two dimensions. The unique example of a three-dimensional material is [Co(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)(1,4-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>). The tpyprz containing compounds [M(tpyprz)(1,2-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Co (<ce:bold>11</ce:bold>), Ni (<ce:bold>15</ce:bold>)) and [Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tpyprz)(1,4-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)]·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>16</ce:bold>) are one-dimensional.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Coordination polymers of Mn(II), Co(II) and Ni(II) prepared by hydrothermal methods.

Structural influence of substituent positions in xylyldiphosphonates.

Prototypical structures of M(II)/xylyldiphosphonate/secondary ligand compounds.

Dimensional expansion via hydrogen bonding.

Recurrent structural motifs in coordination polymers.

Abstract

The hydrothermal reactions of the appropriate metal salt, a xylyldiphosphonic acid and a secondary organonitrogen chelating ligand yielded a series of coordination polymers of the M(II)/xylyldiphosphonate/(organoimine chelate family) with M(II) represented by Mn(II), Co(II) and Ni(II); the 1,2-, 1,3- and 1,4-isomers of xylyldiphosphonate; and the organoimine chelate present as 2,2'-bipyridine (bpy), o-phenanthroline (o-phen) or tetra-2-pyridinylpyrazine (tpyprz). Several representative structural types were observed related to the constraints imposed by the xylyldiphosphonate ligand: the two-dimensional materials [Mn(bpy)(1,2-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (1), [Mn(o-phen)(1,2-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (4) and [Co(o-phen)(1,2-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (7) constructed from {M2(N^N)2(HO3PR)2} clusters linked through the xylyl backbone of the ligands; the network structures of the series [M(bpy)(1,3-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (MMn (2), Co (6), Ni (12) and [M(o-phen)(1,3-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (MMn (5) and Co (8)) which consists of {M2(N^N)2(HO3PR)2} n  chains linked through the xylyl tethers; and the virtual two-dimensional series [M(N^N)2(1,4-H2O3PC8H8PO3H2)(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (MMn, N^Nbpy (3); MCo, N^N o-phen (10); and MNi, N^N o-phen (14)) which contain one-dimensional {M(N^N)2(1,4-H2O3PC8H8PO3H2)} n  2  n  + chains hydrogen-bonded to (HO3PC8H8PO3H)2- anions to provide expansion in two dimensions. The unique example of a three-dimensional material is [Co(o-phen)(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (9). The tpyprz containing compounds [M(tpyprz)(1,2-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (MCo (11), Ni (15)) and [Ni2(tpyprz)(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)]⋅4H2O (16) are one-dimensional.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st005">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Organic–inorganic hybrid materials, including the more specific classes of coordination polymers and metal organic frameworks, have witnessed considerable contemporary development for the rational design of functional materials for technological applications . The synthetic strategy is based on the design of complex structures  constructed from molecular scale composites of inorganic and organic components. In this approach, the inorganic component is a source of magnetic or optical properties, mechanical hardness, thermal stability and potentially reactive sites, while the organic subunits may provide processability, structural diversification and a range of polarizabilities and luminescence properties . Furthermore, metal sites offer variable coordination polyhedra, as well as differences in covalent radii, ligand preferences and crystal field energies, factors which introduce considerable synthetic and structural versatility. By combining the distinct characteristics of the organic and inorganic components, the composite materials provide access to a vast domain of complex, multifunctional structures  with applications ranging from heavy construction to molecular electronics .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Organic-inorganic hybrid materials, including the more specific classes of coordination polymers and metal organic frameworks, have witnessed considerable contemporary development for the rational design of functional materials for technological applications . The synthetic strategy is based on the design of complex structures  constructed from molecular scale composites of inorganic and organic components. In this approach, the inorganic component is a source of magnetic or optical properties, mechanical hardness, thermal stability and potentially reactive sites, while the organic subunits may provide processability, structural diversification and a range of polarizabilities and luminescence properties . Furthermore, metal sites offer variable coordination polyhedra, as well as differences in covalent radii, ligand preferences and crystal field energies, factors which introduce considerable synthetic and structural versatility. By combining the distinct characteristics of the organic and inorganic components, the composite materials provide access to a vast domain of complex, multifunctional structures  with applications ranging from heavy construction to molecular electronics .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Organic–inorganic materials of this type include metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) constructed from metal or metal cluster nodes linked through polyfunctional carboxylate, polypyridyl or polyazaheterocyclic ligands. Such materials have been extensively studied by Yaghi and co-workers , Féréy and co-workers , Kitagawa and co-workers  and Long and co-workers  among others .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Organic-inorganic materials of this type include metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) constructed from metal or metal cluster nodes linked through polyfunctional carboxylate, polypyridyl or polyazaheterocyclic ligands. Such materials have been extensively studied by Yaghi and co-workers , Féréy and co-workers , Kitagawa and co-workers  and Long and co-workers  among others .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">However, metal-organophosphonates represent the prototypical organic–inorganic hybrid materials, whose earliest representatives are the layered materials first reported in the 1970s by Alberti and Clearfield . Since that time, there has been a remarkable growth in the field . Phosphonates are ligands that typically form layered and “pillared layer” materials. “Pillared layer” materials constructed from organodiphosphonate ligands are three-dimensional frameworks with alternating organic and inorganic domains (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>), whose interlamellar separations may be varied by modification of the tether lengths and whose interlamellar structure may be sculpted by appropriate functionalization of the organic tethers .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: However, metal-organophosphonates represent the prototypical organic-inorganic hybrid materials, whose earliest representatives are the layered materials first reported in the 1970s by Alberti and Clearfield . Since that time, there has been a remarkable growth in the field . Phosphonates are ligands that typically form layered and "pillared layer" materials. "Pillared layer" materials constructed from organodiphosphonate ligands are three-dimensional frameworks with alternating organic and inorganic domains ( ), whose interlamellar separations may be varied by modification of the tether lengths and whose interlamellar structure may be sculpted by appropriate functionalization of the organic tethers .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">While α,ωα, ω-alkyldiphosphonates have been extensively studied, the coordination chemistry of the corresponding xylyldiphosphonates, that is, 1,2-, 1,3- and 1–4- (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>), remains relatively unexplored . In the course of our systematic investigations of metal-organodiphosphonate chemistry , we have also noted that the introduction of ancillary ligands such as bipyridine (bpy), <ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phenanthroline (<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen) or tetra-2-pyridinylpyrazine (tpyprz) can have dramatic structural consequences, most commonly resulting in lower dimensionality rather than the prototypical three-dimensional “pillared layer” motif. In this contribution, we present the syntheses and structures of a series of Mn(II), Co(II) and Ni(II) complexes of xylyldiphosphonate ligands with ancillary bipyridyl, <ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phenanthroline and tetrapyridylpyrazine ligands: [Mn(bpy)(1,2-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf [Ni(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(1,4-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf elements.clean_text: While α,ωα, ω-alkyldiphosphonates have been extensively studied, the coordination chemistry of the corresponding xylyldiphosphonates, that is, 1,2-, 1,3- and 1-4- (H2O3PCH2)2C6H4 ( ), remains relatively unexplored . In the course of our systematic investigations of metal-organodiphosphonate chemistry , we have also noted that the introduction of ancillary ligands such as bipyridine (bpy), o-phenanthroline (o-phen) or tetra-2-pyridinylpyrazine (tpyprz) can have dramatic structural consequences, most commonly resulting in lower dimensionality rather than the prototypical three-dimensional "pillared layer" motif. In this contribution, we present the syntheses and structures of a series of Mn(II), Co(II) and Ni(II) complexes of xylyldiphosphonate ligands with ancillary bipyridyl, o-phenanthroline and tetrapyridylpyrazine ligands: [Mn(bpy)(1,2-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (1), [Mn(bpy)(1,3-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (2), [Mn(bpy)2(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)(H2O3PC8H8PO3H2)] (3), [Mn(o-phen)(1,2-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (4), [Mn(o-phen)(1,3-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (5), [Co(bpy)(1,3-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (6), [Co(o-phen)(1,2-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (7), [Co(o-phen)(1,3-HOPC8H8PO3H)] (8), [Co(o-phen)(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (9), [Co(o-phen)2(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)(1,4-H2O3PC8H8PO3H2)] (10), [Co(tpyprz)(1,2-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (11), [Ni(bpy)(1,3-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (12), [Ni(o-phen)(1,3-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (13), [Ni(o-phen)2(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H2)(1,4-H2O3PC8H8PO3H2)] (14), [Ni(tpyprz)(1,2-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (15) and [Ni2(tpyprz)(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)2]⋅4H2O (16⋅4H2O).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st010">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st015">General procedures</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">All chemicals were used as obtained without further purification with the exception of <ce:italic>para</ce:italic>-xylenediphosphonic acid, <ce:italic>ortho</ce:italic>-xylenediphosphonic acid and <ce:italic>meta</ce:italic>-xylenediphosphonic acid which were synthesized in a similar fashion to the literature method  using the respective dibromide starting materials. Nickel(II) acetate tetrahydrate (99.9%) and cobalt(II) acetate tetrahydrate (99.9%) were purchased from VWR. Manganese(II) acetate tetrahydrate (99.99%), 2,2′-bipyridine (99%), 1, 10 phenanthroline (<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen) (99%), tetra-2-pyridinylpyrazine (97%), and hydrofluoric acid (48 wt.% in H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) were all purchased from Sigma–Aldrich. All syntheses were carried out in 23-mL poly(tetrafluoroethylene)-lined stainless steel containers under autogeneous pressure. The pH of the solutions were measured prior to and after heating using pHydrion vivid 1–11® pH paper. Water was distilled above 3.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>MΩ in-house using a Barnstead Model 525 Biopure Distilled Water Center.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General procedures

All chemicals were used as obtained without further purification with the exception of para-xylenediphosphonic acid, ortho-xylenediphosphonic acid and meta-xylenediphosphonic acid which were synthesized in a similar fashion to the literature method  using the respective dibromide starting materials. Nickel(II) acetate tetrahydrate (99.9%) and cobalt(II) acetate tetrahydrate (99.9%) were purchased from VWR. Manganese(II) acetate tetrahydrate (99.99%), 2,2'-bipyridine (99%), 1, 10 phenanthroline (o-phen) (99%), tetra-2-pyridinylpyrazine (97%), and hydrofluoric acid (48 wt.% in H2O) were all purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. All syntheses were carried out in 23-mL poly(tetrafluoroethylene)-lined stainless steel containers under autogeneous pressure. The pH of the solutions were measured prior to and after heating using pHydrion vivid 1-11® pH paper. Water was distilled above 3.0MΩ in-house using a Barnstead Model 525 Biopure Distilled Water Center.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st020">Synthesis of [Mn(bpy)(1,2-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">A solution of manganese(II) acetate tetrahydrate (0.103<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.420<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), 2,2′ bipyridine (0.040<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.256<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), o-xylenediphosphonic acid (0.080<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL, 556<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) with the mole ratio of 1:0.61:0.714:1323 was stirred briefly before heating to 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. The initial and final pH values were 6 and 4, respectively. Yellow rods suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated in 70% yield. IR (KBr pellet, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3405(w), 3058(w), 2927(w), 1595(m), 1573(w), 1490(w), 1438(m), 1241(m), 1111(m), 1081(m), 1064(m), 1036(s), 997(w), 978(w), 917(s), 553(w), 528(w). <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>MnN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: C, 45.5; H, 3.79; N, 5.89. Found: C, 45.4; H, 3.88; N, 5.76%.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Mn(bpy)(1,2-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (1)

A solution of manganese(II) acetate tetrahydrate (0.103g, 0.420mmol), 2,2' bipyridine (0.040g, 0.256mmol), o-xylenediphosphonic acid (0.080g, 0.30mmol), and H2O (10mL, 556mmol) with the mole ratio of 1:0.61:0.714:1323 was stirred briefly before heating to 120°C for 72h. The initial and final pH values were 6 and 4, respectively. Yellow rods suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated in 70% yield. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3405(w), 3058(w), 2927(w), 1595(m), 1573(w), 1490(w), 1438(m), 1241(m), 1111(m), 1081(m), 1064(m), 1036(s), 997(w), 978(w), 917(s), 553(w), 528(w). Anal. Calc. for C18H18MnN2O6P2: C, 45.5; H, 3.79; N, 5.89. Found: C, 45.4; H, 3.88; N, 5.76%.

Synthesis of [Mn(bpy)2(1,4-H2O3PC8H8PO3H2)(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (3)

A solution of manganese(II) acetate tetrahydrate (0.103g, 0.420mmol), 2,2' bipyridine (0.039g, 0.250mmol), p-xylenediphosphonic acid (0.080g, 0.30mmol), and H2O (10mL, 556mmol) with the mole ratio of 1:0.6:0.714:1323 was stirred briefly before heating to 120°C for 72h. The initial and final pH values were 4 and 3, respectively. Yellow blocks suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated in 5% yield. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3497(m), 3053(w), 3025(w), 2917(w), 1599(m), 1514(m), 1439(w), 1259(m), 1100(s), 1086(s), 989(s), 854(m), 600(m), 542(m). Anal. Calcd. for C36H38MnN4O12P4: C, 48.1; H, 4.23; N, 6.24. Found: C, 48.3; H, 3.98; N, 6.20%.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st095">X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0105" view="all">Structural measurements were performed on a Bruker KAPPA APEX DUO diffractometer containing a APEX II CCD system at low temperature (90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) using graphite-monochromated Mo- Kα radiation (Mo Kα<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073Å) . The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects and absorption using <ce:small-caps>sadabs</ce:small-caps>
. The structures were solved by direct methods. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. After all of the non-hydrogen atoms had been located, the model was refined against <ce:bold>F</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, initially using isotropic and later anisotropic thermal displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms were introduced in calculated positions and refined isotropically. Neutral atom scattering coefficients and anomalous dispersion corrections were taken from the <ce:italic>International Tables</ce:italic>, Vol. C. All calculations were performed using SHELXTL crystallographic software packages .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Structural measurements were performed on a Bruker KAPPA APEX DUO diffractometer containing a APEX II CCD system at low temperature (90K) using graphite-monochromated Mo- Kα radiation (Mo Kα=0.71073Å) . The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects and absorption using sadabs . The structures were solved by direct methods. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. After all of the non-hydrogen atoms had been located, the model was refined against F 2, initially using isotropic and later anisotropic thermal displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms were introduced in calculated positions and refined isotropically. Neutral atom scattering coefficients and anomalous dispersion corrections were taken from the International Tables, Vol. C. All calculations were performed using SHELXTL crystallographic software packages .

Data was collected on samples that ranged between 4– and 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, ramping the temperature at 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/ minute (with the exception of compound <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> which was ramped at 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/ minute) between ∼25– and 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para>
