Magnetic susceptibility studies

The temperature dependent magnetic data were recorded at magnetic field of H =1000 Oe in the temperature range of T =2-300K, in field cooling mode (FC) on samples weighing 20 to -50mg, using a Quantum Design MPMS-XL-7 SQUID magnetometer.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st110">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st115">Syntheses and infrared spectroscopy</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0125" view="all">Hydrothermal syntheses, conventionally carried out in water at 120–250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C at autogenous pressure, have been extended to the routine synthesis of metal oxides and organic–inorganic composite materials . Product composition depends on a number of critical conditions, including pH of the medium, temperature and hence pressure, the presence of structure-directing cations, and the use of mineralizers. Since a variety of cationic and anionic components may be present in solution, those of appropriate size, geometry and charge to fulfill crystal packing requirements may be selected from the mixture in the crystallization process. The technique thus exploits “self-assembly” of a solid phase from soluble precursors at moderate temperatures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Syntheses and infrared spectroscopy

Hydrothermal syntheses, conventionally carried out in water at 120-250°C at autogenous pressure, have been extended to the routine synthesis of metal oxides and organic-inorganic composite materials . Product composition depends on a number of critical conditions, including pH of the medium, temperature and hence pressure, the presence of structure-directing cations, and the use of mineralizers. Since a variety of cationic and anionic components may be present in solution, those of appropriate size, geometry and charge to fulfill crystal packing requirements may be selected from the mixture in the crystallization process. The technique thus exploits "self-assembly" of a solid phase from soluble precursors at moderate temperatures.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0130" view="all">Hydrothermal methods have been exploited for decades in the preparation of metal-diphosphonate materials with pillared layer structures, such as that of the recently described [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(1,4-O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)] . The introduction of auxiliary ligands, such as <ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phenanthroline or 2,2′-bipyridyl, provides a method for reducing the overall dimensionality of the phase by blocking coordination sites at the metal and preventing structural expansion in one or more dimensions. The layers associated with compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>12</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>13</ce:bold> and the two-dimensional hydrogen-bonded assemblies of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>10</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>14</ce:bold> are characteristic examples of the use of simple auxiliary chelates in the design of lower dimensional materials. It is noteworthy that only in the case of compound <ce:bold>9</ce:bold> is a three-dimensional structure encountered.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Hydrothermal methods have been exploited for decades in the preparation of metal-diphosphonate materials with pillared layer structures, such as that of the recently described [Cu2(H2O)2(1,4-O3PC8H8PO3)] . The introduction of auxiliary ligands, such as o-phenanthroline or 2,2'-bipyridyl, provides a method for reducing the overall dimensionality of the phase by blocking coordination sites at the metal and preventing structural expansion in one or more dimensions. The layers associated with compounds 1, 2-8, 12 and 13 and the two-dimensional hydrogen-bonded assemblies of 3, 10 and 14 are characteristic examples of the use of simple auxiliary chelates in the design of lower dimensional materials. It is noteworthy that only in the case of compound 9 is a three-dimensional structure encountered.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0135" view="all">Curiously, our naïve design principles did not extend to the chemistry of the M(II)/tpyprz/xylyldiphosphonate system. Our expectation was that the dipodal tpyprz would bridge metal sites of metal-diphosphonate chains or networks to provide two- or three-dimensional materials, or would decorate the surfaces of chains or networks. Rather unexpectedly, compounds <ce:bold>11</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>15</ce:bold> exhibited one-dimensional structures with one terminus of the tpyprz ligand pendant and uncoordinated. The tpyprz derivative <ce:bold>16</ce:bold> is also one-dimensional, despite the tpyprz adopting the common bridging coordination to provide a {M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tpyprz)} structural rod. It is also noteworthy that the structures of this study are generally quite distinct from those of the copper(II)/xylyldiphosphonate/bpy and <ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen system where numerous molecular species are encountered as well as one- and two-dimensional structures, as described below.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Curiously, our naïve design principles did not extend to the chemistry of the M(II)/tpyprz/xylyldiphosphonate system. Our expectation was that the dipodal tpyprz would bridge metal sites of metal-diphosphonate chains or networks to provide two- or three-dimensional materials, or would decorate the surfaces of chains or networks. Rather unexpectedly, compounds 11 and 15 exhibited one-dimensional structures with one terminus of the tpyprz ligand pendant and uncoordinated. The tpyprz derivative 16 is also one-dimensional, despite the tpyprz adopting the common bridging coordination to provide a {M2(tpyprz)} structural rod. It is also noteworthy that the structures of this study are generally quite distinct from those of the copper(II)/xylyldiphosphonate/bpy and o-phen system where numerous molecular species are encountered as well as one- and two-dimensional structures, as described below.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0140" view="all">Under the mildly acidic conditions of synthesis, the xylyldiphosphonate ligands may adopt a variety of protonated forms, rather than the more common fully deprotonated tetranegative anion {O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>P-R-PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>- <ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> with dramatic consequences to the product composition and structure. Furthermore, as noted previously , changes in the identity of the organic tether of the diphosphonate ligand also result in profound structural consequences. In contrasting the chemistries of metal/xylyldiphosphonates and metal/phenyldiphosphonates for example, the compositional and structural variations may reflect simply the different p<ce:italic>K</ce:italic> values of the parent acids, as well as the geometric consequences of the increased flexibility of the xylyl tether compared to the phenyl spacer.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Under the mildly acidic conditions of synthesis, the xylyldiphosphonate ligands may adopt a variety of protonated forms, rather than the more common fully deprotonated tetranegative anion {O3P-R-PO3}4- - with dramatic consequences to the product composition and structure. Furthermore, as noted previously , changes in the identity of the organic tether of the diphosphonate ligand also result in profound structural consequences. In contrasting the chemistries of metal/xylyldiphosphonates and metal/phenyldiphosphonates for example, the compositional and structural variations may reflect simply the different pK values of the parent acids, as well as the geometric consequences of the increased flexibility of the xylyl tether compared to the phenyl spacer.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0145" view="all">The infrared spectra of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>16</ce:bold> exhibit a pattern of two or three medium to strong bands in the 1000–1200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> range attributed to <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(P-–O) of the phosphonate ligands . In addition, compound <ce:bold>16</ce:bold> uniquely exhibits an intense broad band at <ce:italic>ca</ce:italic>. 3100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> assigned to <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(O-–H) of the coordinated water molecules.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The infrared spectra of compounds 1-16 exhibit a pattern of two or three medium to strong bands in the 1000-1200cm-1 range attributed to ν(P--O) of the phosphonate ligands . In addition, compound 16 uniquely exhibits an intense broad band at ca. 3100cm-1 assigned to ν(O--H) of the coordinated water molecules.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st120">Descriptions of the structures of this study</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0150" view="all">The use of 1,2-xylyldiphosphonate as the ligand provides the series of isomorphous materials [Mn(bpy)(1,2-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Mn(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)(1,2-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), and [Co(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)(1,2-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>). As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>, the structures are two-dimensional with the secondary, capping ligands bpy and <ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen projecting above and below the planes to limit spatial expansion to two dimensions. The structures exhibit the characteristic di-μ (O,O′) phosphonate bridge of two metal square pyramids bridged through phosphonate tetrahedra in a {M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>} ring . The basal plane of each metal site is defined by the oxygen donors of the two bridging diphosphonate tetrahedra and the nitrogen donors of the organonitrogen chelate, bpy or <ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen. The apical site is occupied by an oxygen donor from one terminus of a diphosphonate ligand linking to an adjacent {M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>} unit of the layer. Consequently, each diphosphonate ligand uses one terminus in the μ-O,O′ bridging mode while the second bonds to a single metal site of an adjacent {M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PR)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} or {M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PR)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} cluster. In this fashion each {M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(N^N)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PR)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} cluster is linked to four adjacent clusters to provide the two-dimensional connectivity.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Descriptions of the structures of this study

The use of 1,2-xylyldiphosphonate as the ligand provides the series of isomorphous materials [Mn(bpy)(1,2-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (1), [Mn(o-phen)(1,2-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (4), and [Co(o-phen)(1,2-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (7). As shown in  , the structures are two-dimensional with the secondary, capping ligands bpy and o-phen projecting above and below the planes to limit spatial expansion to two dimensions. The structures exhibit the characteristic di-μ (O,O') phosphonate bridge of two metal square pyramids bridged through phosphonate tetrahedra in a {M2P2O4} ring . The basal plane of each metal site is defined by the oxygen donors of the two bridging diphosphonate tetrahedra and the nitrogen donors of the organonitrogen chelate, bpy or o-phen. The apical site is occupied by an oxygen donor from one terminus of a diphosphonate ligand linking to an adjacent {M2P2O4} unit of the layer. Consequently, each diphosphonate ligand uses one terminus in the μ-O,O' bridging mode while the second bonds to a single metal site of an adjacent {M2(bpy)2(HO3PR)2} or {M2(o-phen)2(HO3PR)2} cluster. In this fashion each {M2(N^N)2(HO3PR)2} cluster is linked to four adjacent clusters to provide the two-dimensional connectivity.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0155" view="all">The linkage pattern provides intralamellar cavities of approximate dimensions 13.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>x ×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å whose perimeters are defined by four {M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(N^N)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PR)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} clusters and four xylyl groups.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0160" view="all">In each case, the distances from the metal to the basal oxygen donors are considerably shorter than those to the apical site: M-–O<ce:inf loc="post">basal</ce:inf> (ave): 2.0519(9)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), 2.048(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), 1.995(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>) and M-–O <ce:inf loc="post">apical</ce:inf>: 2.1207(8)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), 2.113(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) and 2.060(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>). The bond lengths for the Co analogue are significantly shorter than those for the Mn derivative as expected from the decrease in the covalent radius of the transition metal on moving from left to right across the series. The phosphonate protonation sites are also apparent from the P-–O and P-–O(H) bond distances. For example, for compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the average for the unprotonated P-–O distances is 1.5122(9)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, while the P-–O(H) distances are 1.5889(9)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and 1.5711(8)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The linkage pattern provides intralamellar cavities of approximate dimensions 13.5Åx ×9.0Å whose perimeters are defined by four {M2(N^N)2(HO3PR)2} clusters and four xylyl groups.

In each case, the distances from the metal to the basal oxygen donors are considerably shorter than those to the apical site: M--Obasal (ave): 2.0519(9)Å (1), 2.048(1)Å (4), 1.995(1)Å (7) and M--O apical: 2.1207(8)Å (1), 2.113(1)Å (4) and 2.060(1)Å (7). The bond lengths for the Co analogue are significantly shorter than those for the Mn derivative as expected from the decrease in the covalent radius of the transition metal on moving from left to right across the series. The phosphonate protonation sites are also apparent from the P--O and P--O(H) bond distances. For example, for compound 1, the average for the unprotonated P--O distances is 1.5122(9)Å, while the P--O(H) distances are 1.5889(9)Å and 1.5711(8)Å.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0165" view="all">With 1,3-xylyldiphosphonate as the bridging ligand, six isostructural compounds are obtained: the isomorphous series [M(bpy)(1,3-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Mn (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), Co (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>), Ni (<ce:bold>12</ce:bold>)) and [Ni(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)(1,3-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (<ce:bold>13</ce:bold>) and the isomorphous pair [M(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)(1,3-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Mn (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>) and Co (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>)). While the structures are again two-dimensional, the juxtaposition of the {M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(N^N)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-O,O′-phosphonate)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} secondary building units is distinct from that observed for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>7</ce:bold>. Rather than isolated {M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(N^N)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PR)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} clusters as observed previously, this second series of compounds exhibits chains of {M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(N^N)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PR)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} clusters running parallel to the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-axis (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>). Adjacent chains are linked through the xylyl tethers of the diphosphonate ligands to provide expansion into two dimensions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: With 1,3-xylyldiphosphonate as the bridging ligand, six isostructural compounds are obtained: the isomorphous series [M(bpy)(1,3-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (MMn (2), Co (6), Ni (12)) and [Ni(o-phen)(1,3-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (13) and the isomorphous pair [M(o-phen)(1,3-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (MMn (5) and Co (8)). While the structures are again two-dimensional, the juxtaposition of the {M2(N^N)2(μ-O,O'-phosphonate)2} secondary building units is distinct from that observed for 1, 4 and 7. Rather than isolated {M2(N^N)2(HO3PR)2} clusters as observed previously, this second series of compounds exhibits chains of {M2(N^N)2(HO3PR)2} clusters running parallel to the a-axis ( ). Adjacent chains are linked through the xylyl tethers of the diphosphonate ligands to provide expansion into two dimensions.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0170" view="all">The metal sites of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>8</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>12</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>13</ce:bold> exhibit trigonally distorted {MO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} octahedral geometries. As illustrated by compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the {MO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>} face of the polyhedron provides an average bond distance of 2.134(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, while the {MO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N} face exhibits an average bond distance of 2.263(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, with the M-–O distance expanded to 2.211(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The series also exhibits the anticipated contraction in metal donor bond distances upon moving from Mn to Co to Ni: M-–O(ave): 2.153(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Mn), 2.156(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Mn), 2.100(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Co), 2.099(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>, M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Co), 2.079(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (<ce:bold>12</ce:bold>, M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Ni) and 2.075(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (<ce:bold>13</ce:bold>, M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Ni); M-–N(ave): 2.290(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (2, M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Mn), 2.310(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Mn), 2.150(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Co), 2.169(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>, M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Co), 2.102(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Ni) and 2.109(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (<ce:bold>13</ce:bold>, M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Ni). Once again, the protonation sites are revealed by the P-–O and P-–O(H) distances; for example, for compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the average P-–O distance is 1.504(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, while the P-–O(H) distances are 1.584(1)Å and 1.576(1)Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The metal sites of compound 2, 5, 6, 8, 12 and 13 exhibit trigonally distorted {MO4N2} octahedral geometries. As illustrated by compound 2, the {MO3} face of the polyhedron provides an average bond distance of 2.134(1)Å, while the {MO2N} face exhibits an average bond distance of 2.263(1)Å, with the M--O distance expanded to 2.211(1)Å. The series also exhibits the anticipated contraction in metal donor bond distances upon moving from Mn to Co to Ni: M--O(ave): 2.153(1)Å (2, MMn), 2.156(1)Å (5, MMn), 2.100(1)Å (6, MCo), 2.099(2)Å (8, MCo), 2.079(1)Å (12, MNi) and 2.075(3)Å (13, MNi); M--N(ave): 2.290(1)Å (2, MMn), 2.310(2)Å (5, MMn), 2.150(1)Å (6, MCo), 2.169(2)Å (8, MCo), 2.102(1)Å (2, MNi) and 2.109(3)Å (13, MNi). Once again, the protonation sites are revealed by the P--O and P--O(H) distances; for example, for compound 2, the average P--O distance is 1.504(1)Å, while the P--O(H) distances are 1.584(1)Å and 1.576(1)Å.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0175" view="all">The most unusual structures are those of the isomorphous series of virtual two-dimensional networks observed for [Mn(bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(1,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(1,4-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), [Co(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(1,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(1,4-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (<ce:bold>10</ce:bold>) and [Ni(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(1,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(1,4-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (<ce:bold>14</ce:bold>). As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>, the structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is constructed from one-dimensional {Mn(bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(1,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">n</ce:sup>
</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> chains. The building motif departs from the conventional {M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(N^N)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PR)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} unit of the previously discussed examples. In these instances, each metal bonds to two bpy or <ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen ligands and to two H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PR groups from two diphosphonic acid ligands to provide <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-{MO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>} coordination. Adjacent metal octahedra of the chain are linked through the 1,4-diphosphonic acid ligands, each bonding to one metal site through one oxygen of each terminus. The remaining oxygen atoms are protonated.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The most unusual structures are those of the isomorphous series of virtual two-dimensional networks observed for [Mn(bpy)2(1,4-H2O3PC8H8PO3H2)(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (3), [Co(o-phen)2(1,4-H2O3PC8H8PO3H2)(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (10) and [Ni(o-phen)2(1,4-H2O3PC8H8PO3H2)(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (14). As shown in  , the structure of 3 is constructed from one-dimensional {Mn(bpy)2(1,4-H2O3PC8H8PO3H2)} n  2  n  + chains. The building motif departs from the conventional {M2(N^N)2(HO3PR)2} unit of the previously discussed examples. In these instances, each metal bonds to two bpy or o-phen ligands and to two H2O3PR groups from two diphosphonic acid ligands to provide cis-{MO2N4} coordination. Adjacent metal octahedra of the chain are linked through the 1,4-diphosphonic acid ligands, each bonding to one metal site through one oxygen of each terminus. The remaining oxygen atoms are protonated.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0180" view="all">The structure achieves virtual two-dimensional expansion through strong hydrogen bonding between the P-–O(H) groups of the chain and the unprotonated oxygen atoms of the associated but uncoordinated {HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H}<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>- <ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions. As shown in 
<ce:bold>b</ce:bold>, the hydrogen bonding interactions result in two-dimensional network of cationic {Mn(bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">n</ce:sup>
</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> chains linked through charge-compensating {HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H}<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>- <ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions. The {Mn(bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> groups of the layer project above and below the plane into the interlamellar domain. The {Mn(bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> groups from adjacent layers interdigitate to produce a dense structure with minimal void space.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The structure achieves virtual two-dimensional expansion through strong hydrogen bonding between the P--O(H) groups of the chain and the unprotonated oxygen atoms of the associated but uncoordinated {HO3PC8H8PO3H}2- - anions. As shown in  b, the hydrogen bonding interactions result in two-dimensional network of cationic {Mn(bpy)2(H2O3PC8H8PO3H2} n  2  n  + chains linked through charge-compensating {HO3PC8H8PO3H}2- - anions. The {Mn(bpy)2}2+ groups of the layer project above and below the plane into the interlamellar domain. The {Mn(bpy)2}2+ groups from adjacent layers interdigitate to produce a dense structure with minimal void space.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0185" view="all">The protonation sites are revealed by the appearance of peaks at locations consistent with P-–O(H) hydrogens and by comparisons of the P-–O and P-–O(H) bond distances in compounds <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>10</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>14</ce:bold>. The hydrogen bonding distances and O-–H⋯O angles are provided in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0015"></ce:float-anchor>. The usual trends in M-–O and M-–N distances are observed: M–O(ave): 2.092(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Mn), 2.052(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (<ce:bold>10</ce:bold>, M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Co), and 2.0460(9)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (<ce:bold>14</ce:bold>, M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Ni); M-N(ave): 2.273(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Mn), 2.148(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (<ce:bold>10</ce:bold>, M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Co), and 2.096(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (<ce:bold>14</ce:bold>, M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Ni).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The protonation sites are revealed by the appearance of peaks at locations consistent with P--O(H) hydrogens and by comparisons of the P--O and P--O(H) bond distances in compounds 3, 10 and 14. The hydrogen bonding distances and O--H⋯O angles are provided in  . The usual trends in M--O and M--N distances are observed: M-O(ave): 2.092(1)Å (3, MMn), 2.052(1)Å (10, MCo), and 2.0460(9)Å (14, MNi); M-N(ave): 2.273(1)Å (3, MMn), 2.148(1)Å (10, MCo), and 2.096(1)Å (14, MNi).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0190" view="all">The unique example of a three-dimensional structure is provided by compound <ce:bold>9</ce:bold>, [Co(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)(1,4-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)]. Once again, the common {M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(N^N)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PR)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} secondary building unit is encountered. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>, these clusters fuse into chains in a fashion reminiscent of structures <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>8</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>12</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>13</ce:bold>. However, in this case, each chain is linked through the 1,4-diphosphonate ligand to four adjacent chains, rather than two, to provide expansion into three dimensions. An unusual feature of the structure is the large cavities running parallel to the c-axis, formed by four {M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PR)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} clusters and the four bridging 1,4-xylyl groups, which are occupied by the <ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen ligands. Consequently, the <ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen groups, which decorate the surfaces of the layers in the previously described two-dimensional series, are incorporated into organic capsules within the three-dimensional framework of <ce:bold>9</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The unique example of a three-dimensional structure is provided by compound 9, [Co(o-phen)(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)]. Once again, the common {M2(N^N)2(HO3PR)2} secondary building unit is encountered. As shown in  , these clusters fuse into chains in a fashion reminiscent of structures 2, 5, 6, 8, 12 and 13. However, in this case, each chain is linked through the 1,4-diphosphonate ligand to four adjacent chains, rather than two, to provide expansion into three dimensions. An unusual feature of the structure is the large cavities running parallel to the c-axis, formed by four {M2(HO3PR)2} clusters and the four bridging 1,4-xylyl groups, which are occupied by the o-phen ligands. Consequently, the o-phen groups, which decorate the surfaces of the layers in the previously described two-dimensional series, are incorporated into organic capsules within the three-dimensional framework of 9.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0195" view="all">The ligand tpyprz was introduced in the naïve expectation that this bridging, binucleating group would provide expansion into three-dimensional structures. However, as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>, the structures of [Co(tpyprz)(1,2-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (<ce:bold>11</ce:bold>) and [Ni(tpyprz)(1,2-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (<ce:bold>15</ce:bold>) are one-dimensional. The structure of <ce:bold>11</ce:bold> is constructed from the {Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tpyprz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PR)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} clusters, linked through the xylyl tethers of the ligand. The coordination geometry at each Co(II) site is {CoN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>} distorted octahedral. Each cobalt site coordinates to two oxygen donors of the {M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(di-μ-O,O′-phosphonate)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} unit, an oxygen donor from a third diphosphonate ligand and the three nitrogen donors of the tpyprz ligand. Each diphosphonate ligand directs one terminus to the di-μ-O,O′ bridging mode, while the second terminus bonds through a single oxygen donor to a cobalt site of an adjacent cluster. The protonation sites of the phosphonate oxygen atoms are clearly revealed by the P-–O(H) distances.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The ligand tpyprz was introduced in the naïve expectation that this bridging, binucleating group would provide expansion into three-dimensional structures. However, as shown in  , the structures of [Co(tpyprz)(1,2-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (11) and [Ni(tpyprz)(1,2-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (15) are one-dimensional. The structure of 11 is constructed from the {Co2(tpyprz)2(HO3PR)2} clusters, linked through the xylyl tethers of the ligand. The coordination geometry at each Co(II) site is {CoN3O3} distorted octahedral. Each cobalt site coordinates to two oxygen donors of the {M2(di-μ-O,O'-phosphonate)2} unit, an oxygen donor from a third diphosphonate ligand and the three nitrogen donors of the tpyprz ligand. Each diphosphonate ligand directs one terminus to the di-μ-O,O' bridging mode, while the second terminus bonds through a single oxygen donor to a cobalt site of an adjacent cluster. The protonation sites of the phosphonate oxygen atoms are clearly revealed by the P--O(H) distances.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0200" view="all">An unusual feature of the structures of <ce:bold>11</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>15</ce:bold> is the coordination geometry of the tpyprz ligand which coordinates to a single metal site. This observation may reflect the reaction conditions: metal to ligand ratio and the acidity of the reaction medium. Since catenation of {M(tpyprz)} groups is not uncommon, as in [{Co<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(tpyprz)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>{Mo<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>)O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>P(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}] , it is also likely that <ce:bold>11</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>15</ce:bold> may serve as building blocks for bimetallic materials with two- or three-dimensional structures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: An unusual feature of the structures of 11 and 15 is the coordination geometry of the tpyprz ligand which coordinates to a single metal site. This observation may reflect the reaction conditions: metal to ligand ratio and the acidity of the reaction medium. Since catenation of {M(tpyprz)} groups is not uncommon, as in [{Co4(tpyprz)3{Mo5O15)O3P(CH2)2PO3}] , it is also likely that 11 and 15 may serve as building blocks for bimetallic materials with two- or three-dimensional structures.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0205" view="all">The structure of [Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tpyprz)(1,4-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)]·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>16</ce:bold>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) is also one-dimensional (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>). In this case, the tpyprz ligand adopts the more common bridging mode between two coordinated metal sites. Once again, the {M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(di-μ-O,O′-phosphonate)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} cluster building unit is observed. The clusters are linked through the xylyl tethers of the diphosphonate ligands and the tpyprz ligands. Each Ni(II) adopts distorted octahedral {NiO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>} geometry with a meridional configuration of donor groups. Each nickel site bonds to two oxygen donors from two diphosphonate ligands in the {Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(di-μ-O,O′-phosphonate)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} unit and a third oxygen donor from a diphosphonate ligand bridging to an adjacent cluster. The remaining coordination sites are occupied by the nitrogen donors of one terminus of the tpyprz ligand. The 1,4-xylyl geometry provides sufficient spacing between the ––PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H termini of the ligand to allow the tpyprz ligand to bridge adjacent {Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PR)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} clusters and nestle between xylyl tethers linking these clusters.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The structure of [Ni2(tpyprz)(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)]⋅4H2O (16⋅4H2O) is also one-dimensional ( ). In this case, the tpyprz ligand adopts the more common bridging mode between two coordinated metal sites. Once again, the {M2(di-μ-O,O'-phosphonate)2} cluster building unit is observed. The clusters are linked through the xylyl tethers of the diphosphonate ligands and the tpyprz ligands. Each Ni(II) adopts distorted octahedral {NiO3N3} geometry with a meridional configuration of donor groups. Each nickel site bonds to two oxygen donors from two diphosphonate ligands in the {Ni2(di-μ-O,O'-phosphonate)2} unit and a third oxygen donor from a diphosphonate ligand bridging to an adjacent cluster. The remaining coordination sites are occupied by the nitrogen donors of one terminus of the tpyprz ligand. The 1,4-xylyl geometry provides sufficient spacing between the --PO3H termini of the ligand to allow the tpyprz ligand to bridge adjacent {Ni2(HO3PR)2} clusters and nestle between xylyl tethers linking these clusters.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st125">Structural trends and generalizations</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0210" view="all">The structures of this study exhibit the influences of incorporation of a secondary chelating ligand which serves to occupy coordination sites on the metal with the effect of reducing the overall dimensionality of the materials. This observation is quite evident in comparing the one- and two-dimensional structures of this study with the conventional pillared layer structure of [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(1,4-O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)] in the absence of a secondary ligand . It is instructive to compare the structures of this study with those of the previously reported copper series .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structural trends and generalizations

The structures of this study exhibit the influences of incorporation of a secondary chelating ligand which serves to occupy coordination sites on the metal with the effect of reducing the overall dimensionality of the materials. This observation is quite evident in comparing the one- and two-dimensional structures of this study with the conventional pillared layer structure of [Cu2(H2O)2(1,4-O3PC8H8PO3)] in the absence of a secondary ligand . It is instructive to compare the structures of this study with those of the previously reported copper series .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0215" view="all">In addition to the secondary ligand, the coordination preferences of the metal also provide a significant structural determinant. Thus, while the structure of [Cu(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)(1,2-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] is similar to those of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>7</ce:bold>, [Cu(bpy)(1,3-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] and [Cu(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)(1,3-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)] are one-dimensional with structures most similar to that of [Ni(tpyprz)(1,2-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] rather than those of 1,3-xylyl diphosphonate series. Furthermore, the copper sites are five coordinate rather than six coordinate.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In addition to the secondary ligand, the coordination preferences of the metal also provide a significant structural determinant. Thus, while the structure of [Cu(o-phen)(1,2-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] is similar to those of compounds 1, 4, and 7, [Cu(bpy)(1,3-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] and [Cu(o-phen)(1,3-HO3PC8H8PO3)] are one-dimensional with structures most similar to that of [Ni(tpyprz)(1,2-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] rather than those of 1,3-xylyl diphosphonate series. Furthermore, the copper sites are five coordinate rather than six coordinate.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0220" view="all">With 1,4-xylyldiphosphonate, the copper series includes the molecular species [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(1,4-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(1,4-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] and [Cu(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)(1,4-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] and the one-dimensional [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(1,4-O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)], as well as the two-dimensional materials [Cu(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)(1,4-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] and [Cu(bpy)(1,4-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)]. These layered structures share common features with [Co(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)(1,2-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] and compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> ad <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> of this study. In all cases, the network is constructed from {M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(di-μ-O,O′-phosphonate)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} clusters linked through the xylyl tethers. Five coordination of the metal centers is also observed for these structures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: With 1,4-xylyldiphosphonate, the copper series includes the molecular species [Cu2(H2O)2(bpy)2(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H2)2(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] and [Cu(H2O)(o-phen)(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] and the one-dimensional [Cu2(o-phen)(H2O)2(1,4-O3PC8H8PO3)], as well as the two-dimensional materials [Cu(o-phen)(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] and [Cu(bpy)(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)]. These layered structures share common features with [Co(o-phen)(1,2-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] and compounds 1, 4 ad 7 of this study. In all cases, the network is constructed from {M2(di-μ-O,O'-phosphonate)2} clusters linked through the xylyl tethers. Five coordination of the metal centers is also observed for these structures.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0225" view="all">A rather obvious structural determinant is the relative locations of the methylenephosphonate groups on the ligand phenyl rings, whether 1,2-, 1,3- or 1,4-substituted. Thus, the two-dimensional structures incorporating (1,2-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>-, <ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> are distinct from the network structures adopted by the (1,3-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>- <ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> series, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>8</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>12</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>13</ce:bold>, while the (1,4-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>- series <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>10</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>14</ce:bold> adopts a one-dimensional chain structure, expanded to two-dimensions through hydrogen-bonding.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: A rather obvious structural determinant is the relative locations of the methylenephosphonate groups on the ligand phenyl rings, whether 1,2-, 1,3- or 1,4-substituted. Thus, the two-dimensional structures incorporating (1,2-HO3PC8H8PO3H)2-, -, 1, 4 and 7 are distinct from the network structures adopted by the (1,3-HO3PC8H8PO3H)2- - series, 2, 5, 6, 8, 12 and 13, while the (1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)2 -- series 3, 10 and 14 adopts a one-dimensional chain structure, expanded to two-dimensions through hydrogen-bonding.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0230" view="all">The structures of these series also reflect the free rotation of the H<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>- <ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> groups about the methylene carbon atoms. For example, in the virtual two-dimensional series <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>10</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>14</ce:bold>, the H<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>- <ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> groups are disposed in the <ce:italic>syn</ce:italic> configuration with respect to the phenyl rings while in the three-dimensional material <ce:bold>9</ce:bold>, the substituents adopt the <ce:italic>anti</ce:italic> limiting geometry (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0045"></ce:float-anchor>). This rotational versatility is also apparent in the previously reported copper series of xylyldiphosphonates.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The structures of these series also reflect the free rotation of the H n PO3- - groups about the methylene carbon atoms. For example, in the virtual two-dimensional series 3, 10 and 14, the H n PO3- - groups are disposed in the syn configuration with respect to the phenyl rings while in the three-dimensional material 9, the substituents adopt the anti limiting geometry ( ). This rotational versatility is also apparent in the previously reported copper series of xylyldiphosphonates.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0235" view="all">Structural variability is additionally enhanced by accessibility of different coordination polyhedra for the metals, variable coordination of aqua ligands and the flexibility of the M-–O-–P angle. In addition, variable protonation of the phosphonate ligands is also encountered. Under the acidic condition of this study, the ligands are generally observed in the symmetrically protonated form (HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>-. <ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>. Under neutral or basic conditions, the fully deprotonated (O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>- <ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> is expected to exhibit different coordination requirements, a hypothesis which we will address in future work.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Structural variability is additionally enhanced by accessibility of different coordination polyhedra for the metals, variable coordination of aqua ligands and the flexibility of the M--O--P angle. In addition, variable protonation of the phosphonate ligands is also encountered. Under the acidic condition of this study, the ligands are generally observed in the symmetrically protonated form (HO3PC8H8PO3H)2-. -. Under neutral or basic conditions, the fully deprotonated (O3PC8H8PO3)4- - is expected to exhibit different coordination requirements, a hypothesis which we will address in future work.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st130">Thermal analyses</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0240" view="all">The thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) plots of the metal(II) compounds of this study (M(II)<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Mn, Co, Ni) exhibit four common motifs in the analysis of decomposition products. For many compounds, the decomposition process does not appear to be complete at a temperature of 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, as evidenced by the gradual loss continuing at the limiting temperature of the instrument. All TGA profiles can be found in the ESI.†.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal analyses

The thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) plots of the metal(II) compounds of this study (M(II)Mn, Co, Ni) exhibit four common motifs in the analysis of decomposition products. For many compounds, the decomposition process does not appear to be complete at a temperature of 800°C, as evidenced by the gradual loss continuing at the limiting temperature of the instrument. All TGA profiles can be found in the ESI.†.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0245" view="all">The TGA for compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits stability up to about 280<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C followed by a weight loss of about 40% at 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, attributed to the loss of the 2,2′-bipyridine ligand (32.8%, theoretical). The compound then has a stable plateau from around 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to 510<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, followed by an additional weight loss of about 20% at 600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Over this range the diphosphonate ligand is decomposing resulting in the condensation of the hydrogen phosphonate groups and the oxidation and loss of P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>
. The residue, which is most likely a manganese oxide is stable from 600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Compounds <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>11</ce:bold> exhibit similar features in their respective TGA plots.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The TGA for compound 1 exhibits stability up to about 280°C followed by a weight loss of about 40% at 400°C, attributed to the loss of the 2,2'-bipyridine ligand (32.8%, theoretical). The compound then has a stable plateau from around 400°C to 510°C, followed by an additional weight loss of about 20% at 600°C. Over this range the diphosphonate ligand is decomposing resulting in the condensation of the hydrogen phosphonate groups and the oxidation and loss of P2O5 . The residue, which is most likely a manganese oxide is stable from 600°C to 800°C. Compounds 4, 5, and 11 exhibit similar features in their respective TGA plots.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0250" view="all">The TGA for compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> exhibits a loss of about 20% (17.4%, calculated) at about 290<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C attributed to the pyrolysis of one of the organonitrogen ligands. The second organo-nitrogen ligand then is slowly lost from about 290<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to about 660<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The total weight loss, including that attributed to first organonitrogen ligand, is about 30% (34.8%, calculated). The compound is then stable from around 660<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. It is interesting to note that the hydrogen-bonded {1,4-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H}<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>- <ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> is so integral to the complex that even at 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C there is no evidence of its loss. The resultant amorphous residue is most likely the metal diphosphonate complex. Similar behavior is exhibited in compounds <ce:bold>10</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>14</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The TGA for compound 3 exhibits a loss of about 20% (17.4%, calculated) at about 290°C attributed to the pyrolysis of one of the organonitrogen ligands. The second organo-nitrogen ligand then is slowly lost from about 290°C to about 660°C. The total weight loss, including that attributed to first organonitrogen ligand, is about 30% (34.8%, calculated). The compound is then stable from around 660°C to 800°C. It is interesting to note that the hydrogen-bonded {1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H}2- - is so integral to the complex that even at 800°C there is no evidence of its loss. The resultant amorphous residue is most likely the metal diphosphonate complex. Similar behavior is exhibited in compounds 10 and 14.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0255" view="all">The TGA of compound <ce:bold>12</ce:bold> is consistent with unusual thermal stability, with a single major weight loss observed. The compound is thermally stable up to ca. 475<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, whereupon there is a weight loss of about 30% between 475<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, corresponding to the loss of the 2,2′-bipyridine ligand (32.6%,theoretical). Between 600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to and 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C there is a gradual weight loss of <<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10%, mostly likely corresponding to the gradual decomposition of the diphosphonate ligand. Compounds <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>7</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>8</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>9</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>13</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>15</ce:bold> exhibit similar behavior to compound <ce:bold>12</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The TGA of compound 12 is consistent with unusual thermal stability, with a single major weight loss observed. The compound is thermally stable up to ca. 475°C, whereupon there is a weight loss of about 30% between 475°C and 600°C, corresponding to the loss of the 2,2'-bipyridine ligand (32.6%,theoretical). Between 600°C to and 800°C there is a gradual weight loss of <10%, mostly likely corresponding to the gradual decomposition of the diphosphonate ligand. Compounds 6, 7, 8, 9, 13 and 15 exhibit similar behavior to compound 12.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0260" view="all">The TGA for compound <ce:bold>16</ce:bold>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O exhibits a loss of about 8% (7.6%, calculated) from around 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C attributed to the loss of the two of the waters of crystallization. The compound is then stable from ca. 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to 440<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The next weight loss occurs between 440<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to about 510<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, where the compound loses the remaining waters of crystallization. The total weight loss over these two ranges is about 15% (13%, calculated). From 510<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C the compound continues to gradually loose mass, most likely due to the decomposition of the organonitrogen ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The TGA for compound 16⋅4H2O exhibits a loss of about 8% (7.6%, calculated) from around 25°C to 200°C attributed to the loss of the two of the waters of crystallization. The compound is then stable from ca. 200°C to 440°C. The next weight loss occurs between 440°C to about 510°C, where the compound loses the remaining waters of crystallization. The total weight loss over these two ranges is about 15% (13%, calculated). From 510°C to 800°C the compound continues to gradually loose mass, most likely due to the decomposition of the organonitrogen ligands.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st135">Magnetism</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0265" view="all">The temperature dependent magnetic susceptibilities of the majority of the compounds of this study were investigated. Compounds <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>12</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>13</ce:bold> were not included in the study due to the presence of paramagnetic impurities which precluded meaningful interpretations of the magnetic properties.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Magnetism

The temperature dependent magnetic susceptibilities of the majority of the compounds of this study were investigated. Compounds 3, 12 and 13 were not included in the study due to the presence of paramagnetic impurities which precluded meaningful interpretations of the magnetic properties.

</ce:para><ce:para id="p0280" view="all">The results for the Curie–Weiss analyses are given in

The Mn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> exhibit <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>μ<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf> values in the range 5.98 to –6.38 38<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μμ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf>, consistent with the <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5/2 ground state (5.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>±<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μμ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf>, calculated). The Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> compounds <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>11</ce:bold> show <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>μ<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf> values in the 3.90 to –4.57 57<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μμ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf> range, consistent with the <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3/2 ground state. The deviations from the spin only value of 3.87 87<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μμ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf> reflects the contributions of spin–orbit coupling. The Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> compounds <ce:bold>14</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>16</ce:bold> with <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>μ<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf> values in the 2.89–3.28 28<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μμ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf> range, are consistent with an <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1 ground state (2.83<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μμ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf>, calculated) with contributions from spin–orbit coupling. These results suggest negligible magnetic exchange through the {M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(di-μμ-O,O′-phosphonate)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} bridges exhibited by many of the compounds of this study.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
As a function of the magnetic moment, the expression is:   χ =   χ   h   + TIP =     μ   eff   2     8 [ T - θ ]   + TIP,   where  (2)    μ   eff   2   =   g   2   S ( S + 1 )    

The results for the Curie-Weiss analyses are given in   (see  for plots of the temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibilities and of the effective magnetic moments). The Mn2+ compounds 1, 2, 4 and 5 exhibit μμeff values in the range 5.98 to -6.38 38μμB, consistent with the S =5/2 ground state (5.9±μμB, calculated). The Co2+ compounds 6-11 show μμeff values in the 3.90 to -4.57 57μμB range, consistent with the S =3/2 ground state. The deviations from the spin only value of 3.87 87μμB reflects the contributions of spin-orbit coupling. The Ni2+ compounds 14-16 with μμeff values in the 2.89-3.28 28μμB range, are consistent with an S =1 ground state (2.83μμB, calculated) with contributions from spin-orbit coupling. These results suggest negligible magnetic exchange through the {M2(di-μμ-O,O'-phosphonate)2} bridges exhibited by many of the compounds of this study.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st140">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0285" view="all">Hydrothermal methods have been used to prepare a series of coordination polymers of the general type M(II)/xylyldiphosphonate/organoimine chelate. Several recurrent structural prototypes were observed reflecting the identity of the xylyldiphosphonate ligand. The materials [M(N^N)(1,2-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] with M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Mn(II), N^N<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>bpy (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), <ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) and M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Co(II), N^N<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>
<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>) exhibit a two-dimensional structure constructed from the ubiquitous {M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(di-μ-O,O′-phosphonate)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} rings linked through the xylyl backbones of the ligands. While the series [M(bpy)(1,3-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Mn (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), Co (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>), Ni (<ce:bold>12</ce:bold>) and [M(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)(1,3-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Mn (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>), Co (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>)) are also two-dimensional, the networks are constructed from {M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(N^N)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PR)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> chains linked through the xylyl tethers of the diphosphonate ligands. The layered structures of [M(N^N)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(1,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(1,4-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Mn, N^N<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>bpy (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>); M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Co, N^N<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>
<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen (<ce:bold>10</ce:bold>); M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Ni, N^N<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>
<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen (<ce:bold>14</ce:bold>)) exhibit {M(N^N)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(1,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">n</ce:sup>
</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> chains linked through hydrogen-bonded (HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions to provide the dimensional expansion.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Hydrothermal methods have been used to prepare a series of coordination polymers of the general type M(II)/xylyldiphosphonate/organoimine chelate. Several recurrent structural prototypes were observed reflecting the identity of the xylyldiphosphonate ligand. The materials [M(N^N)(1,2-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] with MMn(II), N^Nbpy (1), o-phen (4) and MCo(II), N^N o-phen (7) exhibit a two-dimensional structure constructed from the ubiquitous {M2(di-μ-O,O'-phosphonate)2} rings linked through the xylyl backbones of the ligands. While the series [M(bpy)(1,3-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (MMn (2), Co (6), Ni (12) and [M(o-phen)(1,3-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (MMn (5), Co (8)) are also two-dimensional, the networks are constructed from {M2(N^N)2(HO3PR)2} n  chains linked through the xylyl tethers of the diphosphonate ligands. The layered structures of [M(N^N)2(1,4-H2O3PC8H8PO3H2)(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (MMn, N^Nbpy (3); MCo, N^N o-phen (10); MNi, N^N o-phen (14)) exhibit {M(N^N)2(1,4-H2O3PC8H8PO3H2)} n  2  n  + chains linked through hydrogen-bonded (HO3PC8H8PO3H)2- anions to provide the dimensional expansion.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0290" view="all">Although tpyprz was introduced in the naïve expectation that this rigid binucleating ligand would favor two- or three-dimensional structures, the compounds [M(tpyprz)(1,2-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (M<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>Co (<ce:bold>11</ce:bold>), Ni (<ce:bold>15</ce:bold>)) and [Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tpyprz)(1,4-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)]·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>16</ce:bold>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) are one-dimensional. In the case of <ce:bold>11</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>15</ce:bold>, one terminus of the tpyprz ligand is pendant and uncoordinated, and the structures are similar to those of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> but with the metals in a six coordinate {MO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>} environment rather than the square pyramidal {MO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} coordination of the latter series. While the tpyprz ligand of <ce:bold>16</ce:bold> is present as a binucleating rod linking two M(II) sites, this does not accomplish expansion into two-dimensions, as the 1,4-xylyldiphosphonate ligand can effectively span the distance between {Ni<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tpyprz)(di-μ-O,O′-diphosphonate)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} secondary building units.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Although tpyprz was introduced in the naïve expectation that this rigid binucleating ligand would favor two- or three-dimensional structures, the compounds [M(tpyprz)(1,2-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (MCo (11), Ni (15)) and [Ni2(tpyprz)(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)]⋅4H2O (16⋅4H2O) are one-dimensional. In the case of 11 and 15, one terminus of the tpyprz ligand is pendant and uncoordinated, and the structures are similar to those of 1, 4 and 7 but with the metals in a six coordinate {MO3N3} environment rather than the square pyramidal {MO3N2} coordination of the latter series. While the tpyprz ligand of 16 is present as a binucleating rod linking two M(II) sites, this does not accomplish expansion into two-dimensions, as the 1,4-xylyldiphosphonate ligand can effectively span the distance between {Ni2(tpyprz)(di-μ-O,O'-diphosphonate)2} secondary building units.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0295" view="all">The only example of a three-dimensional structure is [Co(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)(1,4-HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H)] (<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>) where the common {Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(di-μ-O,O′-phosphonate)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} building blocks are linked into {Co(<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen)(HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PR)}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> chains which are in turn linked to four adjacent chains through the 1,4-xylyl framework of the ligands. Spatial expansion is accomplished in this instance as a consequence of the <ce:italic>para</ce:italic>-xylyl geometry and the <ce:italic>anti</ce:italic>-configuration of the (HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>P-) –) substituents to provide cavities, defined by four {Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PR)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>} clusters linked through four –C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>-tethers, sufficiently spacious to accommodate the <ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phen ligands within the framework.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The only example of a three-dimensional structure is [Co(o-phen)(1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (9) where the common {Co2(o-phen)2(di-μ-O,O'-phosphonate)2} building blocks are linked into {Co(o-phen)(HO3PR)} n  chains which are in turn linked to four adjacent chains through the 1,4-xylyl framework of the ligands. Spatial expansion is accomplished in this instance as a consequence of the para-xylyl geometry and the anti-configuration of the (HO3P-) -) substituents to provide cavities, defined by four {Co2(HO3PR)4} clusters linked through four -C8H8-tethers, sufficiently spacious to accommodate the o-phen ligands within the framework.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0300" view="all">The structural systematics of these series of compounds demonstrate the general principle of designing lower dimensional polymers (1-D and 2-D) by occupying metal coordination sites with secondary chelating ligands. However, the interplay of relative ligand sizes and geometries also plays a role in the ultimate structure, as noted for compound <ce:bold>9</ce:bold>. Of course, other structural determinants, such as accessibility of different coordination polyhedra, variable aqua coordination, variable protonation and coordination of phosphonate oxygen atoms, and the flexibility of the M-–O-–P valence angle also contribute as structural determinants. Reaction conditions such as stoichiometry, temperature and pH in particular also play significant roles in determining the product composition and structure.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The structural systematics of these series of compounds demonstrate the general principle of designing lower dimensional polymers (1-D and 2-D) by occupying metal coordination sites with secondary chelating ligands. However, the interplay of relative ligand sizes and geometries also plays a role in the ultimate structure, as noted for compound 9. Of course, other structural determinants, such as accessibility of different coordination polyhedra, variable aqua coordination, variable protonation and coordination of phosphonate oxygen atoms, and the flexibility of the M--O--P valence angle also contribute as structural determinants. Reaction conditions such as stoichiometry, temperature and pH in particular also play significant roles in determining the product composition and structure.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st175">Supplementary material</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0335" view="all">CCDC 881705–881717 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>16</ce:bold>. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via <ce:inter-ref id="ir0015" xlink:href="http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif" xlink:type="simple">http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif</ce:inter-ref>. The supplementary data consists of tables of atomic positional parameters, bond lengths, bond angles, anisotropic temperature factors, and calculated hydrogen atom positions for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>16</ce:bold> (Supplementary Tables S1–S78). In addition, ORTEP views of the structures are provided in Supplementary Figs. S1–S16, infrared spectra in Figs. S17–S32, TGA profiles in Figs. S33–S48 and magnetic susceptibility plots in Figs. S49–S61. Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at <ce:inter-ref id="ir0005" xlink:href="doi:10.1016/j.ica.2013.03.003" xlink:type="simple">http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ica.2013.03.003</ce:inter-ref>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Supplementary material

CCDC 881705-881717 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for Compounds 1-16. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. The supplementary data consists of tables of atomic positional parameters, bond lengths, bond angles, anisotropic temperature factors, and calculated hydrogen atom positions for 1-16 (Supplementary Tables S1-S78). In addition, ORTEP views of the structures are provided in Supplementary Figs. S1-S16, infrared spectra in Figs. S17-S32, TGA profiles in Figs. S33-S48 and magnetic susceptibility plots in Figs. S49-S61. Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ica.2013.03.003.

Synthesis of [Mn(bpy)(1,2-HO3PC8H8PO3H)] (1)

The initial and final pH values were 6 and 4, respectively. Yellow rods suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated in 70% yield. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 2880(w), 2344(w), 1570(m), 1587(w), 1399(s), 1307(w), 1274(w), 1250(m), 1180(m), 1161(s), 1136(s), 1076(w), 1057(s), 991(w), 793(m), 753(s), 738(m), 530(m), 505(w), 482(w). Anal. Calcd. for C32H26CoN6O6P2: C, 54.0; H, 3.65; N, 11.8. Found: C, 53.5; H, 3.24; N, 11.7%.

A solution of nickel(II) acetate tetrahydrate (0.074g, 0.30mmol), 2,2'-bipyridine (0.068g, 0.44mmol), m-xylenediphosphonic acid (0.080g, 0.30mmol), and H2O (5mL, 278mmol) with the mole ratio of 1:1.5:1:927 was stirred briefly before heating to 120°C for 72h. The initial and final pH values were 4 and 3, respectively. Green blocks suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated in 10% yield. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3073(m), 3005(m), 2948(m), 2916(m), 2362(w), 1601(s), 1474(m), 1440(s), 1289(w), 1268(w), 1251(s), 1227(s), 1132(s), 1117(w), 1061(s), 1022(w), 919(m), 910(m), 803(w), 737(m), 700(m), 522(s). A solution of nickel(II) acetate tetrahydrate (0.074g, 0.30mmol), 1,10 phenanthroline (0.068g, 0.38mmol), m-xylene-diphosphonic acid (0.080g, 0.30mmol), and H2O (5mL, 278mmol) with the mole ratio of 1:1.23:1:927 was stirred briefly before heating to 120°C for 48h. Magnetic susceptibility studies

The temperature dependent magnetic data were recorded at magnetic field of H =1000 Oe in the temperature range of T =2-300K, in field cooling mode (FC) on samples weighing 20 to -50mg, using a Quantum Design MPMS-XL-7 SQUID magnetometer.

The linkage pattern provides intralamellar cavities of approximate dimensions 13.5Åx ×9.0Å whose perimeters are defined by four {M2(N^N)2(HO3PR)2} clusters and four xylyl groups.

In each case, the distances from the metal to the basal oxygen donors are considerably shorter than those to the apical site: M--Obasal (ave): 2.0519(9)Å (1), 2.048(1)Å (4), 1.995(1)Å (7) and M--O apical: 2.1207(8)Å (1), 2.113(1)Å (4) and 2.060(1)Å (7). The bond lengths for the Co analogue are significantly shorter than those for the Mn derivative as expected from the decrease in the covalent radius of the transition metal on moving from left to right across the series. The phosphonate protonation sites are also apparent from the P--O and P--O(H) bond distances. For example, for compound 1, the average for the unprotonated P--O distances is 1.5122(9)Å, while the P--O(H) distances are 1.5889(9)Å and 1.5711(8)Å.

The metal sites of compound 2, 5, 6, 8, 12 and 13 exhibit trigonally distorted {MO4N2} octahedral geometries. As illustrated by compound 2, the {MO3} face of the polyhedron provides an average bond distance of 2.134(1)Å, while the {MO2N} face exhibits an average bond distance of 2.263(1)Å, with the M--O distance expanded to 2.211(1)Å. The series also exhibits the anticipated contraction in metal donor bond distances upon moving from Mn to Co to Ni: M--O(ave): 2.153(1)Å (2, MMn), 2.156(1)Å (5, MMn), 2.100(1)Å (6, MCo), 2.099(2)Å (8, MCo), 2.079(1)Å (12, MNi) and 2.075(3)Å (13, MNi); M--N(ave): 2.290(1)Å (2, MMn), 2.310(2)Å (5, MMn), 2.150(1)Å (6, MCo), 2.169(2)Å (8, MCo), 2.102(1)Å (2, MNi) and 2.109(3)Å (13, MNi). Once again, the protonation sites are revealed by the P--O and P--O(H) distances; for example, for compound 2, the average P--O distance is 1.504(1)Å, while the P--O(H) distances are 1.584(1)Å and 1.576(1)Å.

The protonation sites are revealed by the appearance of peaks at locations consistent with P--O(H) hydrogens and by comparisons of the P--O and P--O(H) bond distances in compounds 3, 10 and 14. The hydrogen bonding distances and O--H⋯O angles are provided in  . The usual trends in M--O and M--N distances are observed: M-O(ave): 2.092(1)Å (3, MMn), 2.052(1)Å (10, MCo), and 2.0460(9)Å (14, MNi); M-N(ave): 2.273(1)Å (3, MMn), 2.148(1)Å (10, MCo), and 2.096(1)Å (14, MNi).

The TGA for compound 1 exhibits stability up to about 280°C followed by a weight loss of about 40% at 400°C, attributed to the loss of the 2,2'-bipyridine ligand (32.8%, theoretical). The compound then has a stable plateau from around 400°C to 510°C, followed by an additional weight loss of about 20% at 600°C. Over this range the diphosphonate ligand is decomposing resulting in the condensation of the hydrogen phosphonate groups and the oxidation and loss of P2O5 . The residue, which is most likely a manganese oxide is stable from 600°C to 800°C. Compounds 4, 5, and 11 exhibit similar features in their respective TGA plots.

The TGA for compound 3 exhibits a loss of about 20% (17.4%, calculated) at about 290°C attributed to the pyrolysis of one of the organonitrogen ligands. The second organo-nitrogen ligand then is slowly lost from about 290°C to about 660°C. The total weight loss, including that attributed to first organonitrogen ligand, is about 30% (34.8%, calculated). The compound is then stable from around 660°C to 800°C. It is interesting to note that the hydrogen-bonded {1,4-HO3PC8H8PO3H}2- - is so integral to the complex that even at 800°C there is no evidence of its loss. The resultant amorphous residue is most likely the metal diphosphonate complex. Similar behavior is exhibited in compounds 10 and 14.

The TGA of compound 12 is consistent with unusual thermal stability, with a single major weight loss observed. The compound is thermally stable up to ca. 475°C, whereupon there is a weight loss of about 30% between 475°C and 600°C, corresponding to the loss of the 2,2'-bipyridine ligand (32.6%,theoretical). Between 600°C to and 800°C there is a gradual weight loss of <10%, mostly likely corresponding to the gradual decomposition of the diphosphonate ligand. Compounds 6, 7, 8, 9, 13 and 15 exhibit similar behavior to compound 12.

The TGA for compound 16⋅4H2O exhibits a loss of about 8% (7.6%, calculated) from around 25°C to 200°C attributed to the loss of the two of the waters of crystallization. The compound is then stable from ca. 200°C to 440°C. The next weight loss occurs between 440°C to about 510°C, where the compound loses the remaining waters of crystallization. The total weight loss over these two ranges is about 15% (13%, calculated). From 510°C to 800°C the compound continues to gradually loose mass, most likely due to the decomposition of the organonitrogen ligands.

</ce:para><ce:para id="p0280" view="all">The results for the Curie–Weiss analyses are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0020"></ce:float-anchor> (see  for plots of the temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibilities and of the effective magnetic moments). The Mn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> exhibit <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>μ<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf> values in the range 5.98 to –6.38 38<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μμ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf>, consistent with the <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5/2 ground state (5.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>±<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μμ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf>, calculated). The Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> compounds <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>11</ce:bold> show <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>μ<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf> values in the 3.90 to –4.57 57<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μμ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf> range, consistent with the <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3/2 ground state. The deviations from the spin only value of 3.87 87<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μμ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf> reflects the contributions of spin–orbit coupling. The Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> compounds <ce:bold>14</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>16</ce:bold> with <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>μ<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf> values in the 2.89–3.28 28<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μμ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf> range, are consistent with an <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1 ground state (2.83<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μμ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf>, calculated) with contributions from spin–orbit coupling. These results suggest negligible magnetic exchange through the {M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(di-μμ-O,O′-phosphonate)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} bridges exhibited by many of the compounds of this study.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
As a function of the magnetic moment, the expression is:   χ =   χ   h   + TIP =     μ   eff   2     8 [ T - θ ]   + TIP,   where  (2)    μ   eff   2   =   g   2   S ( S + 1 )    

The results for the Curie-Weiss analyses are given in   (see  for plots of the temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibilities and of the effective magnetic moments). The Mn2+ compounds 1, 2, 4 and 5 exhibit μμeff values in the range 5.98 to -6.38 38μμB, consistent with the S =5/2 ground state (5.9±μμB, calculated). The Co2+ compounds 6-11 show μμeff values in the 3.90 to -4.57 57μμB range, consistent with the S =3/2 ground state. The deviations from the spin only value of 3.87 87μμB reflects the contributions of spin-orbit coupling. The Ni2+ compounds 14-16 with μμeff values in the 2.89-3.28 28μμB range, are consistent with an S =1 ground state (2.83μμB, calculated) with contributions from spin-orbit coupling. These results suggest negligible magnetic exchange through the {M2(di-μμ-O,O'-phosphonate)2} bridges exhibited by many of the compounds of this study.
